text:
You're waiting to turn right out of a minor road. It's clear to the left but a lorry is 
coming from the right. Why should you wait, even if you have enough time to turn?

options.A: The lorry could suddenly speed up
options.B: The load on the lorry might be unstable
options.C: The lorry might be slowing down
options.D: Anything overtaking the lorry will be hidden from view

explanation: Anything overtaking the lorry will be hidden from view. Large vehicles can hide overtaking traffic from your view.

text:
You're following a long
vehicle as it approaches a
crossroads. What should
you do if it signals left but
moves out to the right?

options.A: Get closer in order to pass it quickly
options.B: Overtake it as it starts to slow down
options.C: Assume the signal is wrong and that it's turning right
options.D: Stay well back and give it room

explanation: It will take longer to overtake. Large vehicles require more time and distance to overtake safely.

text:
You're following a long 
vehicle approaching a 
crossroads. What should 
you do if the driver signals right but moves close to the left-hand kerb?

options.A: Report the driver to the police
options.B: Warn the driver about the wrong signal

explanation: Leave plenty of room. Motorcycles can be blown off course by strong winds or your vehicle's draft.

text:
Youâ€™re approaching a 
mini-roundabout. What 
should you do if a long 
vehicle in front signals left but positions over to the right?

options.D: Follow the same course as the lorry

explanation: The driver might not be able to see you. Large vehicles have significant blind spots where you may not be visible.

text:
You're driving on a single
carriageway road. Why
should you keep well back
while you're following a
large vehicle?

options.A: To give yourself acceleration space if you decide to overtake
options.B: To offer other drivers a safe gap if they want to overtake you
options.C: To leave a gap in case the vehicle stops and rolls back
options.D: To get the best view of the road ahead

explanation: Allow extra room. Buses and coaches need wide turning circles, especially at junctions.

text:
You're following a lorry on a wet road. What should you do when spray makes it 
difficult to see the road 
ahead?

options.A: Drop back until you can see better
options.B: Put your headlights on full beam
options.C: Keep close to the lorry, away from the spray

explanation: The vehicle could be carrying oversized loads. Agricultural vehicles often carry wide or long loads.

text:
You're leaving a safe gap
as you follow a large
vehicle. What should you do
if a car moves into this gap?
explanation: It will take a long time to overtake. Slow-moving agricultural vehicles require extra time to pass safely.

text:
What should you do
when you're approaching a
bus that's signalling to move
away from a bus stop?

options.B: Allow it to pull away, if it's safe to do so
options.C: Flash your headlights as you approach
options.D: Signal left and wave the bus on

explanation: Give them plenty of room. Powered wheelchairs and mobility scooters need space and consideration.

text:
What should you do if
you want to overtake a long,
slow-moving vehicle on a
busy road?

options.A: Follow it closely and keep moving out to see the road ahead
options.B: Flash your headlights for the oncoming traffic to give way
options.C: Stay behind until the driver waves you past
options.D: Keep well back so that you get a good view of the road ahead

explanation: Drop back to increase your view. Following too closely restricts your view of the road ahead.

text:
What should you do as
you approach this lorry?

options.A: Make the lorry wait for you
options.B: Slow down and be prepared to wait
options.C: Move to the right-hand side of the road
options.D: Flash your lights at the lorry

explanation: Drop back and give more space. Large vehicles obstruct your view and need extra following distance.

text:
You're following a large
vehicle as it approaches a
crossroads. What should
you do if the driver signals
to turn left?

options.A: Wait for the vehicle to finish turning
options.B: Overtake if there are no oncoming vehicles
options.C: Overtake if you can leave plenty of room
options.D: Wait for the driver to cancel their signal

explanation: The driver might not be able to see you in their mirrors. Large vehicle blind spots mean drivers may not see you.

text:
Why is it more difficult to
overtake a large vehicle than
a car?

options.A: It will take longer to overtake a large vehicle
options.B: A large vehicle will be fitted with a speed limiter
options.C: A large vehicle will have air brakes
options.D: It will take longer for a large vehicle to accelerate

explanation: Stay well back. Horse riders need plenty of space as horses can be unpredictable.

text:
It's very windy. What
should you do if you're
behind a motorcyclist who's
overtaking a high-sided
vehicle?
explanation: Drop back. Following closely restricts your view and reaction time.

text:
What should you do if
there's a bus at a bus stop
ahead of you?

options.A: Pass the bus as quickly as you possibly can
options.B: Watch carefully for the sudden appearance of pedestrians
options.C: Continue at the same speed but sound your horn as a warning
options.D: Flash your lights to warn the driver of your presence

explanation: Their brakes might not be as good as yours. Older vehicles may have less effective braking systems.

text:
What should you be
prepared to do in this
situation?

options.C: Report the driver to the police

explanation: To help them see traffic behind. Motorcyclists shoulder check to see traffic in their blind spots.

text:
Why should drivers be
more careful on roads where
trams also operate?

options.B: Because trams don't have a horn
options.C: Because trams can't stop for cars
options.D: Because trams can't steer to avoid obstructions

explanation: Keep well back. Slow vehicles should be given space, not pressured.

text:
You're towing a caravan.
Which is the safest type of
rear-view mirror to use?
explanation: You won't be able to see ahead. Following large vehicles closely severely restricts forward visibility.

text:
You're driving in heavy traffic on a wet road. Which lights should you use if 
there's a lot of surface 
spray?

options.B: Rear fog lights if visibility is more than 100 metres (328 feet)

explanation: Dipped headlights. Use dipped headlights in heavy spray to help you see and be seen.

text:
What should you do if
you overtake a cyclist when
it's very windy?
explanation: Allow extra room. Strong winds can push cyclists off course, so give extra passing space.
